title.narrative: Negotiation Training for Humanitarian Aid Workers

description.narrative: Humanitarian aid workers are one of the first parties to respond to the consequences of conflict, negotiating access to the area and how to distribute the available resources whilst adhering to the humanitarian principles and the demands from their donor(s). Such complex operations not only require dedicated and highly capable individual aid workers, it also requires effective support structures from regional or (inter)national headquarters. In order to effectively improve the capacity of individuals and organisations, we are working to deliver on three aims: I. Increasing humanitarian access to conflict areas by training the negotiation skills of humanitarian aid workers and mediators; II. Make a valuable, long-term Dutch contribution to the global initiative to strengthen negotiation capacity of the humanitarian aid sector; III. Producing a programme for knowledge and capacity development to support Dutch foreign policy instruments on humanitarian assistance

On the 16th of August 2016, World Humanitarian Day, Clingendael Academy was granted the opportunity by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs to launch a unique new training program for humanitarian aid workers. For four years, Clingendael Academy would extend its negotiation training offer to the humanitarian sector to increase its capacity to provide humanitarian assistance to those in need. After a few months of preparation, the first training was delivered in July 2017 in The Hague with especially created negotiation simulations and interactive exercises. In 2018, Clingendael Academy saw this programme really take off within the sector with ever increasing numbers of applications for our training courses, at times with three applications per available spot. It appears we are meeting a real demand in the humanitarian sector.

We train: 1. staff of headquarter level and regional office level (strategic level, strengthening institutional capacity) 2. Humanitarian aid workers in the field on operational and frontline level (sharing best practices and lessons learned). 3. Humanitarian mediators, a seperate group, who have the trust of both the warring party and humanitarian actors.
Programme expenditure from 2016-11-29 until 2018-12-31
Programme expenditure from 2018-01-01 until 2018-12-31

description.narrative: Guidance and tools on humanitarian negotiation processes are produced and dissemninated to humanitarian organisations and policy-makers. Indicator 1 refers to the support guide, indicators 2 & refer to the digital preparation tool, indicators 4 & 5 refer to material development, indicators 6, 7 & 8 refer to knowledge seminars, and indicators 9 & 10 refer to organisational capacity building. All indicators refer to activities started in 2019.

title.narrative: Confidence in recognizing and responding to negotiation tactics

description.narrative: In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I know how to respond to negotiation tactics used by the negotiating parties" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

title.narrative: Confidence in strategic preparation for negotiations

description.narrative: In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I know how to prepare strategically for a negotiation or mediation process" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 14 respondents (1 female, 12 male, 1 non-disclosed)
Based on 14 respondents (1 female, 12 male, 1 non-disclosed)

description.narrative: In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I am able to analyse the negotiating parties before and during a negotiation " with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 14 respondents (1 female, 12 male, 1 non-disclosed)

title.narrative: Confidence in distinguishing positions, interests and needs

description.narrative: In 2018 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the question: "Do you feel that you can make clear distinctions between needs, interests and positions of the negotiation parties?" with 'confident' or 'very confident'. In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I am able to analyse my counterpart, both before as well as during negotiations" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 170 repondents (63 female, 102 male, 5 non-disclosed)
Based on 170 repondents (63 female, 102 male, 5 non-disclosed)

title.narrative: Confidence in formulating and improving strategies

description.narrative: In 2018 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the question: "I feel I am able to formulate/improve strategies as a negotiator" with 'confident' or 'very confident'.

title.narrative: Confidence in preparing a mandate for negotiations

description.narrative: In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I know what a good mandate should include" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 164 respondents (64 female, 96 male, 4 non-disclosed)
Based on 164 respondents (64 female, 96 male, 4 non-disclosed)

title.narrative: Confidence in strategic preparation for negotiations

description.narrative: In 2017 and 2018 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the question: "How confident are you in using the negotiation preparation tools (i.e. conflict/stakeholder analysis, identifying your own position, interests and needs as well as those of your negotiating partner)?" with 'confident' or 'very confident'. In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I know how to prepare strategically for a negotiation" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 169 repondents (63 female, 102 male, 4 non-disclosed)
Based on 26 respondents (6 female, 7 male, 13 non-disclosed)
Based on 169 repondents (63 female, 102 male, 4 non-disclosed)
Based on 26 respondents (6 female, 7 male, 13 non-disclosed)

title.narrative: Confidence in supporting field staff during negotiations

description.narrative: In 2017 and 2018 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the question: "How confident are you in your ability to support field staff during a negotiation process?" with 'confident' or 'very confident'. In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I know how to support my colleagues during a negotiation" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 170 repondents (64 female, 101 male, 5 non-disclosed)

title.narrative: Confidence in leading a negotiation team

description.narrative: In 2017 and 2018 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the question: "How confident are you in your ability to lead a negotiation process?" with 'confident' or 'very confident'. In 2019 this was measured as the percentage of participants who answered the statement: "I would confidently lead a team during a negotiation process" with 'agree' or 'strongly agree'.

comment.narrative: Based on 173 repondents (64 female, 104 male, 5 non-disclosed)
Based on 27 respondents (6 female, 7 male, 14 non-disclosed)

title.narrative: Average change in score

description.narrative: Average change in participants' score for the knowledge-related question in the post-training test.

comment.narrative: Average increase in score for knowledge-related questions in pre- and post-training tests, based on 112 respondents (34 female, 78 male). Average score increased from 3.61 to 4.7, with a maximum score of 6.

Average increase in score for knowledge-related questions in pre- and post-training tests, based on 134 respondents (42 female, 87 male, 5 non-disclosed). Average score increased from 4.57 to 4.8, with a maximum score of 7.
